column2: Yes, said Glaucon.
column3: Yes, said Glaucon.

column2: BOOK IV.
column3: BOOK i v.

column2: Here Adeimantus interposed a question: How would you answer, Socrates, said he, if a person were to say that you are making these people miserable, and that they are the cause of their own unhappiness; the city in fact belongs to them, but they are none the better for it; whereas other men acquire lands, and build large and handsome houses, and have everything handsome about them, offering sacrifices to the gods on their own account, and practising hospitality; moreover, as you were saying just now, they have gold and silver, and all that is usual among the favourites of fortune; but our poor citizens are no better than mercenaries who are quartered in the city and are always mounting guard?
column3: Here Adeimantus interposed a question: How would you answer, Socrates, said he, if a person were to say that you are making these people miserable, and that they are the cause of their own unhappiness; the city in fact belongs to them, but they are none the better for it; whereas other men acquire lands, and build large and handsome houses, and have everything handsome about them, offering sacrifices to the gods on their own account, and practising hospitality; moreover, as you were saying just now, they have gold and silver, and all that is usual among the favourites of fortune; but our poor citizens are no better than mercenaries who are quartered in the city and are always mounting guard?

column2: Yes, I said; and you may add that they are only fed, and not paid in addition to their food, like other men; and therefore they cannot, if they would, take a journey of pleasure; they have no money to spend on a mistress or any other luxurious fancy, which, as the world goes, is thought to be happiness; and many other accusations of the same nature might be added.
column3: Yes, I said; and you may add that they are only fed, and not paid in addition to their food, like other men; and therefore they cannot, if they would, take a journey of pleasure; they have no money to spend on a mistress or any other luxurious fancy, which, as the world goes, is thought to be happiness; and many other accusations of the same nature might be added.

column2: But, said he, let us suppose all this to be included in the charge.
column3: But, said he, let us suppose all this to be included in the charge.

column2: You mean to ask, I said, what will be our answer?
column3: You mean to ask, I said, what will be our answer?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: If we proceed along the old path, my belief, I said, is that we shall find the answer.
column3: If we proceed along the old path, my belief, I said, is that we shall find the answer.

column2: And our answer will be that, even as they are, our guardians may very likely be the happiest of men; but that our aim in founding the State was not the disproportionate happiness of any one class, but the greatest happiness of the whole; we thought that in a State which is ordered with a view to the good of the whole we should be most likely to find justice, and in the ill-ordered State injustice: and, having found them, we might then decide which of the two is the happier.
column3: And our answer will be that, even as they are, our guardians may very likely be the happiest of men; but that our aim in founding the State was not the disproportionate happiness of any one class, but the greatest happiness of the whole; we thought that in a State which is ordered with a view to the good of the whole we should be most likely to find justice, and in the ill ordered State injustice: and, having found them, we might then decide which of the two is the happier.

column2: At present, I take it, we are fashioning the happy State, not piecemeal, or with a view of making a few happy citizens, but as a whole; and by-and-by we will proceed to view the opposite kind of State. Suppose that we were painting a statue, and some one came up to us and said, Why do you not put the most beautiful colours on the most beautiful parts of the body--the eyes ought to be purple, but you have made them black--to him we might fairly answer, Sir, you would not surely have us beautify the eyes to such a degree that they are no longer eyes; consider rather whether, by giving this and the other features their due proportion, we make the whole beautiful.
column3: At present, I take it, we are fashioning the happy State, not piecemeal, or with a view of making a few happy citizens, but as a whole; and by and by we will proceed to view the opposite kind of State. Suppose that we were painting a statue, and some one came up to us and said, Why do you not put the most beautiful colours on the most beautiful parts of the body-the eyes ought to be purple, but you have made them black-to him we might fairly answer, Sir, you would not surely have us beautify the eyes to such a degree that they are no longer eyes; consider rather whether, by giving this and the other features their due proportion, we make the whole beautiful.

column2: And so I say to you, do not compel us to assign to the guardians a sort of happiness which will make them anything but guardians; for we too can clothe our husbandmen in royal apparel, and set crowns of gold on their heads, and bid them till the ground as much as they like, and no more.
column3: And so I say to you, do not compel us to assign to the guardians a sort of happiness which will make them anything but guardians; for we too can clothe our husbandmen in royal apparel, and set crowns of gold on their heads, and bid them till the ground as much as they like, and no more.

column2: Our potters also might be allowed to repose on couches, and feast by the fireside, passing round the winecup, while their wheel is conveniently at hand, and working at pottery only as much as they like; in this way we might make every class happy--and then, as you imagine, the whole State would be happy.
column3: Our potters also might be allowed to repose on couches, and feast by the fireside, passing round the winecup, while their wheel is conveniently at hand, and working at pottery only as much as they like; in this way we might make every class happy-and then, as you imagine, the whole State would be happy.

column2: But do not put this idea into our heads; for, if we listen to you, the husbandman will be no longer a husbandman, the potter will cease to be a potter, and no one will have the character of any distinct class in the State.
column3: But do not put this idea into our heads; for, if we listen to you, the husbandman will be no longer a husbandman, the potter will cease to be a potter, and no one will have the character of any distinct class in the State.

column2: Now this is not of much consequence where the corruption of society, and pretension to be what you are not, is confined to cobblers; but when the guardians of the laws and of the government are only seeming and not real guardians, then see how they turn the State upside down; and on the other hand they alone have the power of giving order and happiness to the State.
column3: Now this is not of much consequence where the corruption of society, and pretension to be what you are not, is confined to cobblers; but when the guardians of the laws and of the government are only seeming and not real guardians, then see how they turn the State upside down; and on the other hand they alone have the power of giving order and happiness to the State.

column2: We mean our guardians to be true saviours and not the destroyers of the State, whereas our opponent is thinking of peasants at a festival, who are enjoying a life of revelry, not of citizens who are doing their duty to the State.
column3: We mean our guardians to be true saviours and not the destroyers of the State, whereas our opponent is thinking of peasants at a festival, who are enjoying a life of revelry, not of citizens who are doing their duty to the State.

column2: But, if so, we mean different things, and he is speaking of something which is not a State.
column3: But, if so, we mean different things, and he is speaking of something which is not a State.

column2: And therefore we must consider whether in appointing our guardians we would look to their greatest happiness individually, or whether this principle of happiness does not rather reside in the State as a whole.
column3: And therefore we must consider whether in appointing our guardians we would look to their greatest happiness individually, or whether this principle of happiness does not rather reside in the State as a whole.

column2: But if the latter be the truth, then the guardians and auxiliaries, and all others equally with them, must be compelled or induced to do their own work in the best way.
column3: But if the latter be the truth, then the guardians and auxiliaries, and all others equally with them, must be compelled or induced to do their own work in the best way.

column2: And thus the whole State will grow up in a noble order, and the several classes will receive the proportion of happiness which nature assigns to them.
column3: And thus the whole State will grow up in a noble order, and the several classes will receive the proportion of happiness which nature assigns to them.

column2: I think that you are quite right.
column3: I think that you are quite right.

column2: I wonder whether you will agree with another remark which occurs to me.
column3: I wonder whether you will agree with another remark which occurs to me.

column2: What may that be?
column3: What may that be?

column2: There seem to be two causes of the deterioration of the arts.
column3: There seem to be two causes of the deterioration of the arts.

column2: What are they?
column3: What are they?

column2: Wealth, I said, and poverty.
column3: Wealth, I said, and poverty.

column2: How do they act?
column3: How do they act?

column2: The process is as follows: When a potter becomes rich, will he, think you, any longer take the same pains with his art?
column3: The process is as follows: When a potter becomes rich, will he, think you, any longer take the same pains with his art?

column2: Certainly not.
column3: Certainly not.

column2: He will grow more and more indolent and careless?
column3: He will grow more and more indolent and careless?

column2: Very true.
column3: Very true.

column2: And the result will be that he becomes a worse potter?
column3: And the result will be that he becomes a worse potter?

column2: Yes; he greatly deteriorates.
column3: Yes; he greatly deteriorates.

column2: But, on the other hand, if he has no money, and cannot provide himself with tools or instruments, he will not work equally well himself, nor will he teach his sons or apprentices to work equally well.
column3: But, on the other hand, if he has no money, and cannot provide himself with tools or instruments, he will not work equally well himself, nor will he teach his sons or apprentices to work equally well.

column2: Certainly not.
column3: Certainly not.

column2: Then, under the influence either of poverty or of wealth, workmen and their work are equally liable to degenerate?
column3: Then, under the influence either of poverty or of wealth, workmen and their work are equally liable to degenerate?

column2: That is evident.
column3: That is evident.

column2: Here, then, is a discovery of new evils, I said, against which the guardians will have to watch, or they will creep into the city unobserved.
column3: Here, then, is a discovery of new evils, I said, against which the guardians will have to watch, or they will creep into the city unobserved.

column2: What evils?
column3: What evils?

column2: Wealth, I said, and poverty; the one is the parent of luxury and indolence, and the other of meanness and viciousness, and both of discontent.
column3: Wealth, I said, and poverty; the one is the parent of luxury and indolence, and the other of meanness and viciousness, and both of discontent.

column2: That is very true, he replied; but still I should like to know, Socrates, how our city will be able to go to war, especially against an enemy who is rich and powerful, if deprived of the sinews of war.
column3: That is very true, he replied; but still I should like to know, Socrates, how our city will be able to go to war, especially against an enemy who is rich and powerful, if deprived of the sinews of war.

column2: There would certainly be a difficulty, I replied, in going to war with one such enemy; but there is no difficulty where there are two of them.
column3: There would certainly be a difficulty, I replied, in going to war with one such enemy; but there is no difficulty where there are two of them.

column2: How so?
column3: How so?

column2: he asked.
column3: he asked.

column2: In the first place, I said, if we have to fight, our side will be trained warriors fighting against an army of rich men.
column3: In the first place, I said, if we have to fight, our side will be trained warriors fighting against an army of rich men.

column2: That is true, he said.
column3: That is true, he said.

column2: And do you not suppose, Adeimantus, that a single boxer who was perfect in his art would easily be a match for two stout and well-to-do gentlemen who were not boxers?
column3: And do you not suppose, Adeimantus, that a single boxer who was perfect in his art would easily be a match for two stout and well to do gentlemen who were not boxers?

column2: Hardly, if they came upon him at once.
column3: Hardly, if they came upon him at once.

column2: What, now, I said, if he were able to run away and then turn and strike at the one who first came up?
column3: What, now, I said, if he were able to run away and then turn and strike at the one who first came up?

column2: And supposing he were to do this several times under the heat of a scorching sun, might he not, being an expert, overturn more than one stout personage?
column3: And supposing he were to do this several times under the heat of a scorching sun, might he not, being an expert, overturn more than one stout personage?

column2: Certainly, he said, there would be nothing wonderful in that.
column3: Certainly, he said, there would be nothing wonderful in that.

column2: And yet rich men probably have a greater superiority in the science and practise of boxing than they have in military qualities.
column3: And yet rich men probably have a greater superiority in the science and practise of boxing than they have in military qualities.

column2: Likely enough.
column3: Likely enough.

column2: Then we may assume that our athletes will be able to fight with two or three times their own number?
column3: Then we may assume that our athletes will be able to fight with two or three times their own number?

column2: I agree with you, for I think you right.
column3: I agree with you, for I think you right.

column2: And suppose that, before engaging, our citizens send an embassy to one of the two cities, telling them what is the truth: Silver and gold we neither have nor are permitted to have, but you may; do you therefore come and help us in war, and take the spoils of the other city: Who, on hearing these words, would choose to fight against lean wiry dogs, rather than, with the dogs on their side, against fat and tender sheep?
column3: And suppose that, before engaging, our citizens send an embassy to one of the two cities, telling them what is the truth: Silver and gold we neither have nor are permitted to have, but you may; do you therefore come and help us in war, and take the spoils of the other city: Who, on hearing these words, would choose to fight against lean wiry dogs, rather than, with the dogs on their side, against fat and tender sheep?

column2: That is not likely; and yet there might be a danger to the poor State if the wealth of many States were to be gathered into one.
column3: That is not likely; and yet there might be a danger to the poor State if the wealth of many States were to be gathered into one.

column2: But how simple of you to use the term State at all of any but our own!
column3: But how simple of you to use the term State at all of any but our own!

column2: Why so?
column3: Why so?

column2: You ought to speak of other States in the plural number; not one of them is a city, but many cities, as they say in the game.
column3: You ought to speak of other States in the plural number; not one of them is a city, but many cities, as they say in the game.

column2: For indeed any city, however small, is in fact divided into two, one the city of the poor, the other of the rich; these are at war with one another; and in either there are many smaller divisions, and you would be altogether beside the mark if you treated them all as a single State.
column3: For indeed any city, however small, is in fact divided into two, one the city of the poor, the other of the rich; these are at war with one another; and in either there are many smaller divisions, and you would be altogether beside the mark if you treated them all as a single State.

column2: But if you deal with them as many, and give the wealth or power or persons of the one to the others, you will always have a great many friends and not many enemies.
column3: But if you deal with them as many, and give the wealth or power or persons of the one to the others, you will always have a great many friends and not many enemies.

column2: And your State, while the wise order which has now been prescribed continues to prevail in her, will be the greatest of States, I do not mean to say in reputation or appearance, but in deed and truth, though she number not more than a thousand defenders.
column3: And your State, while the wise order which has now been prescribed continues to prevail in her, will be the greatest of States, I do not mean to say in reputation or appearance, but in deed and truth, though she number not more than a thousand defenders.

column2: A single State which is her equal you will hardly find, either among Hellenes or barbarians, though many that appear to be as great and many times greater.
column3: A single State which is her equal you will hardly find, either among Hellenes or barbarians, though many that appear to be as great and many times greater.

column2: That is most true, he said.
column3: That is most true, he said.

column2: And what, I said, will be the best limit for our rulers to fix when they are considering the size of the State and the amount of territory which they are to include, and beyond which they will not go?
column3: And what, I said, will be the best limit for our rulers to fix when they are considering the size of the State and the amount of territory which they are to include, and beyond which they will not go?

column2: What limit would you propose?
column3: What limit would you propose?

column2: I would allow the State to increase so far as is consistent with unity; that, I think, is the proper limit.
column3: I would allow the State to increase so far as is consistent with unity; that, I think, is the proper limit.

column2: Very good, he said.
column3: Very good, he said.

column2: Here then, I said, is another order which will have to be conveyed to our guardians: Let our city be accounted neither large nor small, but one and self-sufficing.
column3: Here then, I said, is another order which will have to be conveyed to our guardians: Let our city be accounted neither large nor small, but one and self sufficing.

column2: And surely, said he, this is not a very severe order which we impose upon them.
column3: And surely, said he, this is not a very severe order which we impose upon them.

column2: And the other, said I, of which we were speaking before is lighter still,--I mean the duty of degrading the offspring of the guardians when inferior, and of elevating into the rank of guardians the offspring of the lower classes, when naturally superior.
column3: And the other, said I, of which we were speaking before is lighter still,--I mean the duty of degrading the offspring of the guardians when inferior, and of elevating into the rank of guardians the offspring of the lower classes, when naturally superior.

column2: The intention was, that, in the case of the citizens generally, each individual should be put to the use for which nature intended him, one to one work, and then every man would do his own business, and be one and not many; and so the whole city would be one and not many.
column3: The intention was, that, in the case of the citizens generally, each individual should be put to the use for which nature intended him, one to one work, and then every man would do his own business, and be one and not many; and so the whole city would be one and not many.

column2: Yes, he said; that is not so difficult.
column3: Yes, he said; that is not so difficult.

column2: The regulations which we are prescribing, my good Adeimantus, are not, as might be supposed, a number of great principles, but trifles all, if care be taken, as the saying is, of the one great thing,--a thing, however, which I would rather call, not great, but sufficient for our purpose.
column3: The regulations which we are prescribing, my good Adeimantus, are not, as might be supposed, a number of great principles, but trifles all, if care be taken, as the saying is, of the one great thing,--a thing, however, which I would rather call, not great, but sufficient for our purpose.

column2: What may that be?
column3: What may that be?

column2: he asked.
column3: he asked.

column2: Education, I said, and nurture: If our citizens are well educated, and grow into sensible men, they will easily see their way through all these, as well as other matters which I omit; such, for example, as marriage, the possession of women and the procreation of children, which will all follow the general principle that friends have all things in common, as the proverb says.
column3: Education, I said, and nurture: If our citizens are well educated, and grow into sensible men, they will easily see their way through all these, as well as other matters which I omit; such, for example, as marriage, the possession of women and the procreation of children, which will all follow the general principle that friends have all things in common, as the proverb says.

column2: That will be the best way of settling them.
column3: That will be the best way of settling them.

column2: Also, I said, the State, if once started well, moves with accumulating force like a wheel.
column3: Also, I said, the State, if once started well, moves with accumulating force like a wheel.

column2: For good nurture and education implant good constitutions, and these good constitutions taking root in a good education improve more and more, and this improvement affects the breed in man as in other animals.
column3: For good nurture and education implant good constitutions, and these good constitutions taking root in a good education improve more and more, and this improvement affects the breed in man as in other animals.

column2: Very possibly, he said.
column3: Very possibly, he said.

column2: Then to sum up: This is the point to which, above all, the attention of our rulers should be directed,--that music and gymnastic be preserved in their original form, and no innovation made.
column3: Then to sum up: This is the point to which, above all, the attention of our rulers should be directed,--that music and gymnastic be preserved in their original form, and no innovation made.

column2: They must do their utmost to maintain them intact.
column3: They must do their utmost to maintain them intact.

column2: And when any one says that mankind most regard
column3: And when any one says that mankind most regard

column2: 'The newest song which the singers have,'
column3: 'The newest song which the singers have,'

column2: they will be afraid that he may be praising, not new songs, but a new kind of song; and this ought not to be praised, or conceived to be the meaning of the poet; for any musical innovation is full of danger to the whole State, and ought to be prohibited.
column3: they will be afraid that he may be praising, not new songs, but a new kind of song; and this ought not to be praised, or conceived to be the meaning of the poet; for any musical innovation is full of danger to the whole State, and ought to be prohibited.

column2: So Damon tells me, and I can quite believe him;--he says that when modes of music change, the fundamental laws of the State always change with them.
column3: So Damon tells me, and I can quite believe him;--he says that when modes of music change, the fundamental laws of the State always change with them.

column2: Yes, said Adeimantus; and you may add my suffrage to Damon's and your own.
column3: Yes, said Adeimantus; and you may add my suffrage to Damon's and your own.

column2: Then, I said, our guardians must lay the foundations of their fortress in music?
column3: Then, I said, our guardians must lay the foundations of their fortress in music?

column2: Yes, he said; the lawlessness of which you speak too easily steals in.
column3: Yes, he said; the lawlessness of which you speak too easily steals in.

column2: Yes, I replied, in the form of amusement; and at first sight it appears harmless.
column3: Yes, I replied, in the form of amusement; and at first sight it appears harmless.

column2: Why, yes, he said, and there is no harm; were it not that little by little this spirit of licence, finding a home, imperceptibly penetrates into manners and customs; whence, issuing with greater force, it invades contracts between man and man, and from contracts goes on to laws and constitutions, in utter recklessness, ending at last, Socrates, by an overthrow of all rights, private as well as public.
column3: Why, yes, he said, and there is no harm; were it not that little by little this spirit of licence, finding a home, imperceptibly penetrates into manners and customs; whence, issuing with greater force, it invades contracts between man and man, and from contracts goes on to laws and constitutions, in utter recklessness, ending at last, Socrates, by an overthrow of all rights, private as well as public.

column2: Is that true?
column3: Is that true?

column2: I said.
column3: I said.

column2: That is my belief, he replied.
column3: That is my belief, he replied.

column2: Then, as I was saying, our youth should be trained from the first in a stricter system, for if amusements become lawless, and the youths themselves become lawless, they can never grow up into well-conducted and virtuous citizens.
column3: Then, as I was saying, our youth should be trained from the first in a stricter system, for if amusements become lawless, and the youths themselves become lawless, they can never grow up into well conducted and virtuous citizens.

column2: Very true, he said.
column3: Very true, he said.

column2: And when they have made a good beginning in play, and by the help of music have gained the habit of good order, then this habit of order, in a manner how unlike the lawless play of the others! will accompany them in all their actions and be a principle of growth to them, and if there be any fallen places in the State will raise them up again.
column3: And when they have made a good beginning in play, and by the help of music have gained the habit of good order, then this habit of order, in a manner how unlike the lawless play of the others! will accompany them in all their actions and be a principle of growth to them, and if there be any fallen places in the State will raise them up again.

column2: Very true, he said.
column3: Very true, he said.

column2: Thus educated, they will invent for themselves any lesser rules which their predecessors have altogether neglected.
column3: Thus educated, they will invent for themselves any lesser rules which their predecessors have altogether neglected.

column2: What do you mean?
column3: What do you mean?

column2: I mean such things as these:--when the young are to be silent before their elders; how they are to show respect to them by standing and making them sit; what honour is due to parents; what garments or shoes are to be worn; the mode of dressing the hair; deportment and manners in general.
column3: I mean such things as these:--when the young are to be silent before their elders; how they are to show respect to them by standing and making them sit; what honour is due to parents; what garments or shoes are to be worn; the mode of dressing the hair; deportment and manners in general.

column2: You would agree with me?
column3: You would agree with me?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: But there is, I think, small wisdom in legislating about such matters,--I doubt if it is ever done; nor are any precise written enactments about them likely to be lasting.
column3: But there is, I think, small wisdom in legislating about such matters,--I doubt if it is ever done; nor are any precise written enactments about them likely to be lasting.

column2: Impossible.
column3: Impossible.

column2: It would seem, Adeimantus, that the direction in which education starts a man, will determine his future life.
column3: It would seem, Adeimantus, that the direction in which education starts a man, will determine his future life.

column2: Does not like always attract like?
column3: Does not like always attract like?

column2: To be sure.
column3: To be sure.

column2: Until some one rare and grand result is reached which may be good, and may be the reverse of good?
column3: Until some one rare and grand result is reached which may be good, and may be the reverse of good?

column2: That is not to be denied.
column3: That is not to be denied.

column2: And for this reason, I said, I shall not attempt to legislate further about them.
column3: And for this reason, I said, I shall not attempt to legislate further about them.

column2: Naturally enough, he replied.
column3: Naturally enough, he replied.

column2: Well, and about the business of the agora, and the ordinary dealings between man and man, or again about agreements with artisans; about insult and injury, or the commencement of actions, and the appointment of juries, what would you say?
column3: Well, and about the business of the agora, and the ordinary dealings between man and man, or again about agreements with artisans; about insult and injury, or the commencement of actions, and the appointment of juries, what would you say?

column2: there may also arise questions about any impositions and exactions of market and harbour dues which may be required, and in general about the regulations of markets, police, harbours, and the like.
column3: there may also arise questions about any impositions and exactions of market and harbour dues which may be required, and in general about the regulations of markets, police, harbours, and the like.

column2: But, oh heavens! shall we condescend to legislate on any of these particulars?
column3: But, oh heavens! shall we condescend to legislate on any of these particulars?
